questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following are not risk factors for developing gestational diabetes?
questions.explanation:
Obesity in first-degree relatives is not a high-risk factor for gestational diabetes mellitus. 
However, severe obesity is a risk factor for developing gestational diabetes. Gestational diabetes mellitus is defined as carbohydrate intolerance of variable severity with onset 
or first recognition during the present pregnancy. It usually presents in the second or third trimester. More than 50% of women with GDM 
ultimately develop overt diabetes within 20 years. It is recommended to screen for gestational diabetes mellitus in the presence of the following 
high-risk factors: • Severe obesity • Strong family history of type-2 diabetes • Previous history of gestational diabetes mellitus • Impaired glucose metabolism or glucosuria.

questions.question:
Question 2: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine USG 
scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect 
overt diabetes?
questions.explanation:
Overt diabetes is when fasting blood sugar is  126 mg/dl. Overt diabetics are women who are 
known to have diabetes before pregnancy. A patient is said to have overt diabetes if: • Fasting blood sugar  126 mg/dL • A random blood sugar of  200 mg/dL • HbA1c of  6.5% The maternal complication of diabetes: • increased Miscarriage and preterm labor. • increased incidence of preeclampsia • polyhydramnios • prolongation of labor due to shoulder dystocia, operative interference, and cephalo-pelvic 
disproportion. Fetal and Neonatal complications of diabetes: • fetal macrosomia (birth weight > 4kg) 496 
Sold by @itachibot • congenital malformations - Musculoskeletal, urogenital, and CNS anomalies.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient underwent a one-step procedure for gestational diabetes screening. Which of the 
following statements regarding this procedure is false?

options.a: Fasting blood glucose  92 mg/dL is diagnostic
options.b: 100 grams of glucose is given after overnight fast

questions.explanation:
In one-step procedure, the patient is given 75g of glucose after an overnight fast, and blood 
glucose is measured hourly for 2 hours. Diagnostic criteria with one-step procedure is as follows: • Fasting  92 mg/dL • 1-hour  180 mg/dL • 2-hour  153 mg/dL In two-step approach patient is given glucose and subsequent values measured in two separate 
steps. • Step 1 - the patient is given 50 grams of glucose and blood glucose is measured after one hour. If 
it is 140 mg/dl then the screen is positive and step 2 is done. • Step 2 - the patient is given 100g of glucose and values measured hourly, for 3 hours. A diagnosis 
is made if at least two values are high using one of two methods. DIPSI (Diabetes In Pregnancy Societies of India) recommends a one-step procedure without 
regard to the time of the last meal. Here the patient is given 75 grams of oral glucose. A blood 
glucose value of 140 mg/dL after 2-hours is diagnostic.

questions.question:
Question 4: A woman at 28 weeks of gestation is started on insulin therapy after being diagnosed with 
gestational diabetes mellitus. What should be the fasting blood glucose target in her? 490 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: The target fasting blood glucose level in a patient with gestational diabetes mellitus is 95 mg/dl. In gestational diabetes mellitus, the targets are: • Fasting  95 mg/dl • 1-h postprandial  140 mg/dl • 2-h postprandial  120 mg/dl • HbA1c  6.0%.

questions.question:
Question 5: According to Priscilla White's classification for diabetes in pregnancy, all of the following 
classes should be managed with insulin except
questions.explanation:
Class A1 is managed by diet therapy. Other than A1, all the other classes are managed by insulin 
therapy. Priscilla White's classification for diabetes in pregnancy is not used anymore. It was modified by 
the American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists in 1986. 497 
Sold by @itachibot Class 
Description Gestational Diabetes Mellitus A1 
Diet-controlled GDM A2 
Insulin-controlled GDM Diabetes Mellitus B 
Onset >20yDuration <10y C 
Onset 10-19yDuration 10-19y D 
Onset <10yDuration >20yBe 
nign retinopathy F 
Nephropathy R 
Proliferative retinopathy H 
Heart disease

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of hyperglycemia 
during pregnancy?

options.a: Metformin crosses the placenta and has teratogenic effects on the fetus
options.b: Diet control is the first line management
options.c: HbA1c monitored at the end of the first trimester and then every 3 months thereafter
options.d: Insulin is the first line pharmacological agent

questions.explanation:
Metformin crosses the placenta. However, no teratogenic effects have been observed as yet. Insulin is the preferred treatment in gestational diabetes mellitus because it does not cross the 
placenta (American Diabetes Association). Management of diabetes in pregnancy: • Preconceptional counseling: • To achieve tight control of diabetes before the onset of pregnancy. • HbA1C level measured to plan pregnancy. • Appropriate advice about diet and insulin given • Antenatal care (at monthly intervals up to 20 weeks and thereafter at 2 weeks intervals): • Diabetic diet—30 ™cal/kg for normal BMI, 24 ™cal/kg for overweight women, and 12 ™cal/kg for 
morbidly obese women • Frequent monitoring of blood glucose • HbA1c determination at the end of the first trimester and then every 3 months thereafter. HbA1c 
level of 6% is desirable • Insulin therapy - initiated when diabetes is not controlled by diet alone • Oral hypoglycemic drugs- glibenclamide and metformin are safe.

questions.question:
Question 7: A primigravida on screening was found to have a fasting blood glucose of more than 100 
mg/dl. Which of the following medications will you not prescribe to her?
questions.explanation:
Tolbutamide is not used for the treatment of gestational diabetes. 498 
Sold by @itachibot First-generation sulfonylureas such as tolbutamide and chlorpropamide can cause teratogenicity, 
neonatal hypoglycemia, and fetal hyperinsulinemia. First-line glycemic control agents in pregnancy: • Insulin • Glyburide • Metformin

questions.question:
Question 8: 491 
Sold by @itachibot A primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation is admitted with preterm labour contractions. She 
was diagnosed with gestational diabetes, on screening. Which of the following tocolytic drugs 
should be avoided in her?
questions.explanation:
Terbutaline should be avoided in pregnant women with diabetes. Terbutaline (-mimetic drugs) given for tocolysis can cause hyperglycemia, which can cause 
diabetic ketoacidosis. Factors precipitating ketoacidosis in pregnancy: • Hyperemesis gravidarum • Infection • Non-compliance • Insulin pump failure • -sympathomimetic drugs • Corticosteroids • Poor glycemic control

questions.question:
Question 9: According to the American college of obstetricians, macrosomia is defined as the fetal birth 
weight of 
.
questions.explanation:
According to the American college of obstetricians (ACOG), macrosomia is defined as the fetal 
birth weight of  4.5 kg. Macrosomia refers to growth beyond a specific threshold, regardless of gestational age. In 
developed countries, the most commonly used threshold is the weight above 4.5 kg, but weight 
above 4 kg is also commonly used. The WHO defines the cut-off at 4.0 kg for fetal macrosomia in its guidelines for the management 
of common maternal conditions. This is followed in India.

questions.question:
Question 10: In gestational diabetes, which of the following is an independent and substantial risk factor 
for macrosomia?
questions.explanation:
BMI (body mass index) is an independent and substantial risk factor for macrosomia in both 
diabetic and non-diabetic mothers. BMI levels are associated with increased birth weight, regardless of glucose levels. Gestational 
diabetes prevalence increases by approximately 1 percent for every 1 kg/m2 increase in BMI. 499 
Sold by @itachibot BMI cutoffs for pregnancy: Underweight - < 18 kg/m2 Normal - 18.5 to 24.9 kg/m2 Overweight - 25 to 29.9 kg/m2 Obese - >30 kg/m2 Weight distribution also seems to play a role because the risk of gestational diabetes is increased 
with truncal obesity. HbA1c levels are associated with fetal malformations in pre-gestational 
diabetes.

questions.question:
Question 11: According to ACOG, routine cesarean delivery is advocated in a woman with gestational 
diabetes mellitus if the sonographically estimated fetal weight is  
 g.
questions.explanation:
According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), routine cesarean 
delivery is advocated in a woman with gestational diabetes mellitus if the sonographically 
estimated fetal weight is  4500 g.

questions.question:
Question 12: A pregnant woman has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and her blood glucose levels are 
well controlled on insulin. What will be the appropriate gestational age for her delivery?
questions.explanation:
The most appropriate time for the delivery in this patient would be 39 weeks as she has good 
glycemic control with insulin. The timing for delivery in a pregnant woman with GDM would vary depending on the control of 
glucose levels & mode of treatment. Appropriate timing for delive

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following complications is unlikely in a patient with gestational diabetes?
questions.explanation:
500 
Sold by @itachibot Polyhydramnios is a complication of diabetes, not oligohydramnios. Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is commonly defined as glucose intolerance first recognized 
during pregnancy. Complications of gestational diabetes: • Spontaneous abortion • Preterm labor • Unexplained fetal demise • Hypoglycemia • Malformations • Altered fetal growth • Hypocalcemia • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy • Pre-eclampsia • Respiratory distress syndrome • Polyhydramnios

questions.question:
Question 14: On screening, a primigravida is found to have fasting blood glucose of 110mg/dl. What is the 
likelihood that she will develop overt diabetes within the next 20 years?
questions.explanation:
50 % of women with gestational diabetes develop overt diabetes within 20 years. Hence, they are 
recommended to undergo screening and revaluation from time to time. Fasting blood glucose of  92 mg/dL indicates gestational diabetes.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 29-year-old woman with overt diabetes comes to you for pre-conception counseling. Which 
of the following congenital heart defects are least likely to occur if she were to have a child?
questions.explanation:
Tetrology of Fallot (TOF) is usually not seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Ventricular septal defect and transposition of great arteries are the most common cardiac 
anomalies in infants of diabetic mothers. Cardiac defects that present more often in infants of diabetic mothers are: • Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) • Double outlet right ventricle (DORV) • Ventricular septal defect (VSD) • Truncus arteriosus • Tricuspid atresia • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) 501 
Sold by @itachibot The most common cardiac anomaly in an infant of a diabetic mother is a controversial topic. Most 
resources mention VSD and TGA are the most common and do not specify which among them is 
more common.

questions.question:
Question 16: Hypocalcemia in a newborn is defined as serum calcium  
 mg/dl.
questions.explanation:
Hypocalcemia in a newborn is defined as serum calcium < 8 mg/dl. Hypocalcemia is one of the potential metabolic derangements in neonates of diabetic mothers. There is hypomagnesemia in the mother and the infant due to increased maternal urinary 
excretion of magnesium due to diabetes. There is maternal hyperparathyroidism due to 
hypomagnesemia which leads to increased maternal calcium. This maternal calcium passes to the infant through the placenta and suppresses fetal PTH 
synthesis and impairs PTH response to postpartum hypocalcemia. PTH suppression, in this case, 
can be severe and lead to convulsions in the early neonatal period and may persist for months.

questions.question:
Question 17: You are performing capillary blood glucose charting for newborns in the post-natal ward. 
Below what level is it considered hypoglycemia?
questions.explanation:
Neonatal hypoglycemia is defined as blood glucose levels <45 mg/dL. Maternal hyperglycemia stimulates the fetal pancreas to secrete excess insulin, which causes 
increased neonatal fat deposition, abdominal girth, and macrosomia (Pederson's hypothesis). It 
also leads to a rapid drop in plasma glucose concentration after delivery.

questions.question:
Question 18: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below. 494 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image showing a poorly developed lower limb suggests the diagnosis of caudal regression 
sequence/sacral agenesis seen in pregestational diabetes. It is the most specific anomaly seen in 
diabetes. The caudal regression sequence is a rare malformation, frequently associated with maternal 
pre-gestational diabetes. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, 
including incomplete development of the sacrum and the lumbar vertebrae. Elevated maternal HbA1c levels correlate with fetal malformations. It occurs approximately 200 
times more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers than in other infants. Overt diabetes (pregestational diabetes) is associated with higher malformation rates than the 
general population. Neural tube defects (encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly), 
transposition of great vessels, ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, hypoplastic left heart, 
aortic stenosis and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen. Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters. Option B: Malformations are not associated with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). 
Malformations occur due to the disruption of organogenesis, usually occurring in the first 502 
Sold by @itachibot trimester. The abnormal glycemic status in GDM manifests only in the second trimester. Option C: Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis. Option D: ACE inhibitors can cause oligohydramnios.

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following will be the most effective contraception in a female with hypertension 
and a history of gestational diabetes mellitus?
questions.explanation:
Intrauterine devices are the most effective contraceptive choice in patients with gestational 
diabetes mellitus and hypertension. It is suitable in patients with diabetes and comorbidities like obesity, hypertension, or 
dyslipidemia. It is a method without potential cardiovascular consequences, unlike hormonal 
contraceptives. Low-dose hormonal contraceptives can be used safely in women with gestational diabetes if there 
are no associated comorbidities. Even though the barrier method will not lead to complications in such patients, the failure rate is 
high due to incorrect use and non-compliance. Hence it is not preferred. Option D: DMPA(depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate) is an injectable hormonal contraceptive 
that is contraindicated in diabetic pregnant women with co-morbidities. 503 
Sold by @itachibot Cardiovascular Conditions in Pregnancy
